title: How to Build a BMX Wooden Ramp

steps.headline: Take a large piece of wood and cut 4 ramp shapes depending on how big you want your jump to be.
Cut groves in the ramp so you can place the support beams in (example-if the ramp is 30 inches (76.2 cm) from the bottom to the take off point cut groves every 10 inches (25.4 cm) .
Screw in the support boards to the two ramp cut outs.
Now you have a frame.
steps.description: Bolt that to a piece of wood so that it doesn't snap.

steps.headline: Screw or nail on plywood over the frame and you have a strong wooden ramp.
steps.description: Make sure ramp does not move or slide.

text: Take a large piece of wood and cut 4 ramp shapes depending on how big you want your jump to be.  Cut groves in the ramp so you can place the support beams in (example-if the ramp is 30 inches (76.2 cm) from the bottom to the take off point cut groves every 10 inches (25.4 cm) .  Screw in the support boards to the two ramp cut outs.  Now you have a frame. Bolt that to a piece of wood so that it doesn't snap. Screw or nail on plywood over the frame and you have a strong wooden ramp. Make sure ramp does not move or slide.
sentences: Take a large piece of wood and cut 4 ramp shapes depending on how big you want your jump to be.
Cut groves in the ramp so you can place the support beams in (example-if the ramp is 30 inches (76.2 cm) from the bottom to the take off point cut groves every 10 inches (25.4 cm) .
Screw in the support boards to the two ramp cut outs.
Bolt that to a piece of wood so that it doesn't snap.
Screw or nail on plywood over the frame and you have a strong wooden ramp.
Make sure ramp does not move or slide.
tyn_section: Metal pipe if your putting a grinding rail at the top
